data.title: All Things Lakers
data.meta_description: An in-depth look at the past and present of the Lakers, the 16-time NBA champions. Bios for every player who ever wore a Lakers uniform, in L.A. and Minneapolis. Every statistic, every season, every title, every Hall of Famer.
data.text:
Forward, #16

Born July 6, 1980

Coached by Bernie Bickerstaff, Mike Brown, Mike D'Antoni, Phil Jackson

Pau Gasol was considered a savior of sorts when he came to the Lakers in February 2008. Fans hoped he could rescue a Lakersâ dream season that was quickly turning into a nightmare.

A former NBA rookie of the year and All-Star with the Memphis Grizzlies, Gasol was traded to the Lakers in his seventh season for a package of draft picks and players, including his younger brother Marc. The deal was considered a steal for the Lakers, who had dropped five of 10 games since big man Andrew Bynum was sidelined with a knee injury.

Gasol did not disappoint. The 7-foot center from Barcelona had 24 points and 12 rebounds in his Lakers debut and averaged 18.8 points, 7.8 rebounds, 3.5 assists and 1.56 blocks a game down the stretch as the team went 22-5 to secure the top seeding in the Western Conference.

The Lakers cruised through the Western Conference playoffs but couldnât get past archrival Boston in the NBA Finals. Gasolâs finesse style of play didnât work against the more physical Celtics and he struggled throughout the series, averaging 14.7 points a game.

Angry fans looking for someone to blame (particularly for a humiliating 131-92 loss in the closeout games) began questioning Gasolâs toughness, mockingly referring to him as Pau "Gasoft."

The insults didnât go unnoticed. "I heard it a lot," he told The Timesâ Bill Plaschke. "I heard it too much."

Gasol decided it was time to toughen up. He started working out several times a week to enable

himself to be a little more physical when necessary during games. By the summer of 2010, Gasol had two NBA championship rings in his possession -â and no one was doubting his toughness anymore.

In the 2009 Finals against Orlando, Gasol averaged 18.6 points and was often the primary defender on Orlandoâs Dwight Howard, whose 15.4 points a game was a dramatic dropoff from the 25.8 he put up against Cleveland in the Eastern Conference finals.

A year later against Boston, Gasol fought his way through the defenders that had knocked him around two years earlier, this time averaging 18.6 points a game. He showed particular resolve in Game 7 as the Lakers battled back from 13 points down, at one point letting out a primal scream after sinking a shot, and finished the game with his third straight double-double (19 points and 18 rebounds).

Gasol played well as the start of the 2010-11 season, earning NBA player of the month honors in November as he helped the Lakers overcome Andrew Bynumâs injury-related absence. He averaged 20.3 points per game and shot 54.1% from the floor during the month. His 28-point performance in a Nov. 21 victory over Golden State marked the sixth time in team history that a player had finished a game with perfect shooting while attempting at least 10 shots (10-for-10 from the floor, eight-for-eight from the line).

As the season progressed, however, inconsistencies began to develop in Gasolâs game. After receiving a pep talk from Kobe Bryant following a disappointing effort in a loss to the Boston Celtics on Jan. 31, Gasol had a productive February, averaging 59.2% shooting and 20.5 points per game. But the good times were fleeting. Gasolâs lackluster playoff performance, which prompted Bryant and Coach Phil Jackson to push him to play more aggressively, ultimately played a role in the Lakersâ Western Conference semifinals loss to eventual NBA champion Dallas.

During the prolonged offseason due to the NBA lockout, Gasol was at the center of potential trade rumors. A deal to send Gasol and Lakers teammate Lamar Odom to the New Orleans Hornets for All-Star point guard Chris Paul was blocked by the NBA just before the start of the 2011-12 season. Gasol said he wouldnât let his near trade by the Lakers affect his play, and his numbers were similar to the previous season.

An injury-marred 2012-13 campaign for Gasol proved costly for the Lakers. Gasol posted career lows in points per game (13.7), field-goal percentage (.466) and games played (49) as he battled ongoing tendinitis in both of his knees. After starting in all 345 games he had played as a Laker, Coach Mike DâAntoni played the four-time All-Star off the bench during seven games in December.

Gasol eventually returned to the starting lineup, but he missed five games in January with a concussion after being elbowed by Denverâs JaVale McGee. The Spaniardâs season was dealt a bigger blow in February when he suffered a torn plantar fascia in his right foot. Gasol missed 20 games because of the injury, but his playing improved as the Lakers managed to qualify for the playoffs following a disappointing start.

Gasol, who is known for his charitable work in the Los Angeles community, is a UNICEF ambassador.
